Citation:
Ala. Code § 8-38-1 et seq.
 Ala. Code § 27-6 (for insurance industry)
Apply to Encrypted Data?:
YES, if the covered entity knows or has reason to know that the encryption key or security credential that could render the information readable has been breached as well.Ala. Code § 8-38-2(6)(b)(2).
 For insurance industry: NO. Ala. Code § 27-3(4)(b).

Citation: Alaska Stat. § 45.48.010 et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, if information is encrypted and encryption key has been accessed or acquired. Alaska Stat. § 45.48.090(7).

Citation: Ariz. Rev. Stat. §18-551 to Ariz. Rev. Stat. §18-552
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation: Ark. Code Ann. § 4-110-101 et seq., “Personal Information Protection Act”
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation: Cal. Civ. Code §1798.82 (as applicable to non-governmental entities); Cal. Civ. Code §1798.29 (as applicable to governmental entities).
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, a breach of encrypted data will trigger a notification requirement if the encryption key or a security credential is also acquired by an unauthorized person, and the owner of licensor of personal information has a reasonable belief that the encryption key or security credential could be used to render the encrypted personal information readable or usable. Cal. Civ. Code §1798.82(a) (as applicable to non-governmental entities); Cal. Civ. Code §1798.29(a) (as applicable to governmental entities).

Citation: Colo. Rev. Stat. § 6-1-716. See also Colo. Rev. Stat. § 24-73-101 et seq., which applies to governmental entities.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES. “The breach of encrypted or otherwise secured personal information must be disclosed in accordance with this section if the confidential process, encryption key, or other means to decipher the secured information was also acquired in the security breach or was reasonably believed to have been acquired.” Colo. Rev. Stat. § 6-1-716(2)(a.4).

Citation: Conn. Gen. Stat. § 36a-701b.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation:
Del. Code tit. 6, § 12B-101 et seq.
 Effective 4/14/18, Del. Code tit. 6, § 12B-100 et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?:
NO.
 Effective 4/14/18, notification is not required if the affected data is encrypted, unless the encryption key is affected as well and the data owner or licensee reasonably believes that the personal information could be rendered readable. Del. Code tit. 6, § 12B-101(1)(b).

Citation:
D.C. Code § 28-3851 et seq. 
 Amended By D.C. Law 23-98, § 2, 67 DCR 3923, eff. 6/17/2020 (Security Breach Protection Amendment Act Of 2020).
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation:
Fla. Stat. § 501.171,
 the “Florida Information Protection Act of 2014.”
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.
NO.

Citation: 9 Guam Code Ann. § 48.10 et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: No. 9 Guam Code Ann. § 48.20.

Citation: Haw. Rev. Stat. § 487N-1 et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, encrypted records or data containing personal information along with the confidential process or key. Haw. Rev. Stat. § 487N-1.

Citation: Idaho Code § 28-51-104, Idaho Code § 28-51-105, Idaho Code § 28-51-106, Idaho Code § 28-51-107.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation: 815 Ill. Comp. Stat. 530/1 et seq., “Personal Information Protection Act”.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES. If breach involves encrypted or redacted data along with the keys needed to unencrypt, unredact, or otherwise read the name or data elements, notification is required. 815 Ill. Comp. Stat. 530/5.

Citation: Ind. Code § 24-4.9-1-1 et seq. (applicable to non-governmental entities); Ind. Code § 4-1-11-1 et seq. (applicable to state and local agencies).
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, if notifier is not a state or local agency and encrypted personal information was or may have been acquired by an unauthorized person with access to the encryption key. Ind. Code § 24-4.9-3-1(a)(2); NO if notifier is a state or local agency.

Citation: Iowa Code § 715C.1 - Iowa Code § 715C.2.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, if information is encrypted and encryption key has been obtained through the breach of security. Iowa Code § 715C.1(11)(a). Encryption is defined to mean a method that meets “accepted industry standards.” Iowa Code § 715C.1(5).

Citation: Kan. Stat. § 50-7a01 et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation: Ky. Rev. Stat. § 365.720 et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation: La. Rev. Stat. § 51:3071 et seq., “Database Security Breach Notification Law”.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation: Me. Rev. Stat. Ann. tit. 10, § 1346 et seq. “the Notice of Risk to Personal Data Act.”
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation:
Md. Code Ann., Com. Law. § 14-3501 et seq.
 Md. Code, Ins. § 4-406 (insurance carriers).
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93H, § 1 et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, if unauthorized acquisition or use of encrypted electronic data and confidential process or key is capable of compromising the security, confidentiality or integrity of personal information. Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93H, § 1(a).

Citation:
Mich. Comp. Laws § 445.61 et seq.
 [For the insurance industry, Mich. Comp. Laws § 500.559 et seq.]
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, if encrypted information was accessed by a person with unauthorized access to the encryption key. Mich. Comp. Laws § 445.72(1)(b); Mich. Comp. Laws § 500.561(1)(b) (insurance industry).

Citation: Minn. Stat. § 325E.61 (applicable to non-government entities); Minn. Stat. § 13.055 (applicable to government entities).
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO

Citation:
Miss. Code § 75-24-29.
 2019 Miss. S.B. 2831 § 6 (for insurance industry).
Apply to Encrypted Data?:
NO.
 For insurance industry (effective Jul. 1, 2019): NO. 2019 Miss. S.B. 2831 § 3(d).

Citation: Mo. Rev. Stat. § 407.1500
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation: Mont. Code § 30-14-1701 et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation: Neb. Rev. Stat. § 87-801 et seq., “Financial Data Protection and Consumer Notification of Data Security Breach Act of 2006.”
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, if the confidential process or key was or is reasonably believed to have been acquired as a result of the breach. Neb. Rev. Stat. § 87-802(3).

Citation: Nev. Rev. Stat. § 603A.010 et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation:
N.H. Rev. Stat. § 359-C:19 et seq., “New Hampshire Right to Privacy Act.”
 For the insurance industry: N.H. Rev. Stat. § 420-P:1 et seq., “Insurance Data Security Law.”
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, if data is acquired in combination with any required key, security code, access code or password that would permit access to the encrypted data. N.H. Rev. Stat. § 359-C:19(II).

Citation: N.J. Rev. Stat. § 56:8-161 et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO (or any other method that renders the information unreadable). N.J. Rev. Stat. § 56:8-161.

Citation: N.M. Stat. Ann. §57-12C-1 et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: Yes, if the confidential process or key used to decrypt the encrypted data is also breached. N.M. Stat. Ann. §57-12C-2(D).

Citation: N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 899-aa (applicable to non-governmental entities); N.Y. State Tech. § 208 (applicable to governmental entities); N.Y. Educ. Law § 2-D (applicable to educational agencies and their third-party contractors).
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation: N.C. Gen. Stat. § 75-61 et seq. “Identity Theft Protection Act”, N.C. Gen. Stat. § 75-65.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, if the encryption key or confidential process has also been breached. N.C. Gen. Stat. § 75-61(14).

Citation:
N.D. Cent. Code § 51-30-01, et seq.; N.D. Cent. Code § 54-NEW-01, et seq.
 For insurance industry, N.D. Cent. Code §§ 26.1-02-01 et. seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation:
Ohio Rev. Code § 1349.19 - Ohio Rev. Code § 1349.192.
 For insurance industry: Ohio Rev. Code § 3965.01 et. seq..
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation: Okla. Stat. tit. 24 § 161 to Okla. Stat. tit. 24 § 166 “Security Breach Notification Act”
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, if encrypted information is accessed and acquired in an unencrypted form or if the security breach involves a person with access to the encryption key and the individual or entity reasonably believes that such breach has caused or will cause identity theft or fraud to any OK resident. Okla. Stat. tit. 24 § 163(B).

Citation: Or. Rev. Stat. § 646A.600 et seq., “Oregon Consumer Information Protection Act.”
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO (also does not apply to redacted data). Or. Rev. Stat. § 646A.602(11)(b)(i).

Citation: 73 Pa. Stat. § 2301 et seq., “Breach of Personal Information Notification Act”
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, if information is acquired in unencrypted form, if the breach involves the security of the encryption, or if it involves a person with access to the key. 73 Pa. Stat. § 2303(b).

Citation: P.R. Laws Ann. tit. 10, § 4051 et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: No. P.R. Laws Ann. tit. 10, § 4051.

Citation: R.I. Gen. Laws § 11-49.3-1 et seq., “Rhode Island Identity Theft Protection Act of 2015.”
Apply to Encrypted Data?: No.

Citation: S.C. Code § 39-1-90. [For the insurance industry, S.C. Code § 38-99-10 et seq.]
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.
YES, provided that the encryption key that would render the compromised data readable is also subject to breach. SB 62, 93rd Sess. (S.D. 2018), eff. 7/1/2018.

Citation:
Tenn. Code § 47-18-2107.
 [Applicable to state insurance licensees] Tenn. Code § 56-2-1001 et seq. (effective July 1, 2021). 2021 Tenn. Pub. Acts. Ch. 345. Insurance Data Security Law, HB 766.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, if encryption key is also compromised by breach. Tenn. Code § 47-18-2107(a)(1)(A). Under the insurance data security law, this also applies related to encryption. Tenn. Code § 56-2-1003(4)(B).

Citation: Tex. Bus. Com. Code § 521.002, Tex. Bus. Com. Code § 521.052, Tex. Bus. Com. Code § 521.053, Tex. Bus. Com. Code § 521.151
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, if person accessing the data has the key required to decrypt the data. Tex. Bus. Com. Code § 521.053(a).

Citation: V.I. Code Ann. tit. 14, §2208 - 2212.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: No.

Citation: Utah Code § 13-44-101 et seq., “Protection of Personal Information Act.”
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation: Vt. Stat. tit. 9, §2430 et seq., “Security Breach Notice Act”
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation:
Va. Code § 18.2-186.6.
 For insurance industry: Va. Code § 38.2-621 (et. seq.).
Apply to Encrypted Data?:
YES, if encrypted information is accessed and acquired in an unencrypted form or if the security breach involves a person with access to the encryption key and the individual or entity reasonably believes that such breach has caused or will cause identity theft or other fraud to any VA resident. Va. Code § 18.2-186.6(C).
 For insurance industry: No Va. Code § 38.2-621

Citation: Wash. Rev. Code § 19.255.010 et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO. “Secured” means encrypted in a manner that meets or exceeds the NIST standard or is otherwise modified so that the PI is rendered unreadable, unusable or undecipherable by an unauthorized person. Notice is required if information acquired and accessed is not secured during a breach or if the confidential process, encryption key or other means to decipher the secured information was acquired by an unauthorized person. Wash. Rev. Code § 19.255.010(1), (7).

Citation: W. Va. Code § 46A-2A-101, et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: YES, if encrypted info. is accessed and acquired in an unencrypted form or if security breach involves a person with access to the encryption key and the individual or entity reasonably believes that such breach has caused or will cause identity theft or other fraud to any WV resident. W. Va. Code § 46A-2A-102(b).

Citation: Wis. Stat. § 134.98.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: NO.

Citation: Wyo. Stat. § 40-12-501 et seq.
Apply to Encrypted Data?: Only applies to non-"redacted” data, with redaction defined as alteration or truncation of data such that no more than 5 digits of the data defined as “personal identifying information” is accessible. Wyo. Stat. § 40-12-501(a)(vii), (a)(viii).
